_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary - Northwest Properties Exchange

EPA Facility Id:  100000233375



This resubmission is due because it has been 5 years since the last submission.  All compliance issues have been met and/or updated per RMP and OSHA requirements.  No new hazards have been identified and there have been no catastrophic incidences during the previous 5 years.  Equipment has been maintained and records made for daily, weekly, monthly, quarterly, bi-annual and annual inspections.  Any issues found were promptly corrected, however there were only regular maintenance per Manufacturers' and EPA/OSHA suggestions. 



This facility is a cold storage warehouse located outside the City of Chelan, Chelan County, State of Washington.



The regulated substance, anhydrous ammonia, is used as a refrigerant.  There is approximately 10,140 lbs of ammonia in the facility, based on receipts for ammonia purchases.



The facility's accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures and management practices.  It is the policy of Management to adhere to all applicable federal and state safety and environmental regulations.  The prevention plan meets all the requirements of OSHA's PSM (Process Safety Management) regulations.



Refrigeration personnel do not respond to large ammonia releases and have not received training in accordance with 29 CFR 1920.120.  Actions to prevent a major release shall be attempted only by refrigeration personnel from an area that is not threatened by release, if possible.  If not possible, they will evacuate.  Other employees will be evacuated or sheltered-in-place as appropriate.  The Fire Department or Hazmat Team will take control of the incident upon arrival at the plant.  An emergency plan has been developed covering notification to public safety agencies and the public.  An evacuation plan for the plant has also been developed and all employees receive training on this plan.  The plan has been rev

iewed with the local fire department.



Ammonia is considered hazardous by EPA and is listed on the Extremely Hazardous Substance list.  Chemical properties of ammonia make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling ammonia in order to:



  Prevent unnecessary human exposure

  Reduce the threat to our personnel

  Reduce the threat to the community and environment





The facility has one engine room and 19 CA rooms.  The largest vessel will hold 13,299 lbs of ammonia, however it will never be filled to capacity but rather up to 80% of capacity (10,755 lbs).  During the past 5 years no ammonia has been added to the system and total ammonia is 10,140 lbs which is spread out through the entire system and never held in one vessel.  Isolation valves are located throughout the facility with remote operation and shutdown capabilities.  The engine room has an outside kill switch and ammonia detector.



Other hazardous substances are used on-site, however they do not meet or exceed the threshold limits established in 40 CFR 68.130.



The policies, procedures and training that have been established will reduce the risk of an accidental hazardous substance release for the safety of it's employees and surroundings. 



The facility complies with OSHA and WA State process safety management rules and regulations, WA State safety regulations, and IIAR standards for good work practices.  The ammonia refrigeration system was installed to standards and local codes.  Piping and equipment is secured and protected, engine room doors are tight fitting and open outwards.  Other safety systems used include:



  Computerized controls, which can be operated remotely

  Suction trap hi-level float

  High discharge pressure shut down

  Low suction pressure shut down

  High discharge temperature shut down

  Oil pressure failure shut own

  High amperes shut down

  Automatic timer to prevent short cycling via computer controls

  Oil filters plugged shut down

250 psi relief on high pressure side, to prevent overpressure situations

  250 psi relief valves on low pressure side, to prevent overpressure situations

  ECPS to equalize low and high pressures



Operating procedures and checklists are used by employees performing operational functions.  Procedures are kept in the refrigeration office.  These procedures include:



  Shut down procedures (routine and emergency)

  Pre-start up safety procedures

  Routine operations

  Maintenance of all equipment

  Response to major and minor releases

  Emergency action plan



This facility is brand new, with construction completed 9/15/2016. In addition to the operating procedures, Management has established Emergency  Response Guidelines for releases involving ammonia.  These procedures are part of the ongoing training.  Coordination of response plans with Chelan County Fire District 7, Washington State Patrol, Chelan County Sheriff and Chelan County Emergency Management is on-going.



Training on ammonia safety and detailed mechanical integrity will be a major ongoing process at the facility.  Review and update of the emergency plan will be done annually and drills and emergency evacuation practices will be executed, also.  Training will be required for all employees who work around the ammonia system, including fork lift personnel.
